questions.question: How did NextEra Energy's exposure to Options - primarily gas evolve from 2022 through 2024 in terms of fair value and volatility assumptions, and what does this reveal about the company's risk positioning in gas derivatives?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, NextEra Energy's fair value of 'Options - primarily gas' decreased from $356 million in assets and $347 million in liabilities to $100 million in assets and $97 million in liabilities by 2023, and further to $100 million in assets and $102 million in liabilities by 2024. The implied volatility for these options also declined from a weighted average of 36% in 2022 to 50% in 2023 and 52% in 2024, indicating a reduction in perceived market volatility and risk over the three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2023) → [Options - Primarily Gas]: Fair value of $100M (assets) and $97M (liabilities), with implied volatility at 50%
Hop 2: [NEE](2024) → [Options - Primarily Gas]: Fair value of $100M (assets) and $102M (liabilities), with implied volatility rising slightly to 52%
Hop 3: [NEE](2022) → [Options - Primarily Gas]: Fair value was significantly higher at $356M (assets) and $347M (liabilities), with implied volatility at 36%

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy's net exposure to forward gas contracts evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this 3-year trend suggest about the company's risk positioning in natural gas markets?
questions.answer: NextEra Energy's net exposure to forward gas contracts increased from $160 million in 2022 (assets of $191M - liabilities of $31M) to $300 million in 2023 (assets of $377M - liabilities of $77M), then declined slightly to $250 million in 2024 (assets of $296M - liabilities of $46M). This pattern shows a significant expansion in gas market participation in 2023 followed by a partial contraction in 2024, suggesting a strategic shift toward greater gas market exposure before reducing positions as market conditions evolved.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2023) → [Forward Contracts - Gas]: Assets of $377M and liabilities of $77M at year-end 2023
Hop 2: [NEE](2024) → [Forward Contracts - Gas]: Assets of $296M and liabilities of $46M at year-end 2024
Hop 3: [NEE](2022) → [Forward Contracts - Gas]: Assets of $191M and liabilities of $31M at year-end 2022

questions.question: How has NextEra Energy Resources' (NEER) reliance on long-term bilateral contracts for its net generating capacity evolved from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend suggest about its risk mitigation strategy in competitive markets?
questions.answer: NEER's reliance on long-term bilateral contracts has steadily increased from 92% of its net generating capacity in 2022, to 94% in both 2023 and 2024. This consistent rise indicates a strategic emphasis on revenue stability and risk mitigation, particularly in volatile energy markets. The company continues to use shorter-term bilateral contracts as a hedge when long-term agreements are not in place, reinforcing its approach to managing price risk in daily spot markets.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2023) → [Long-Term Bilateral Contracts]: 94% of NEER's net generating capacity was committed under long-term contracts as of December 31, 2023.
Hop 2: [NEE](2024) → [Long-Term Bilateral Contracts]: 94% of NEER's net generating capacity remained committed under long-term contracts as of December 31, 2024, showing continuity in strategy.

Hop 3: [NEE](2022) → [Long-Term Bilateral Contracts]: In 2022, approximately 92% of NEER's net generating capacity was committed under long-term contracts, indicating a slight but deliberate increase over the next two years.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table	of	Contents

NEER	has	operations	that	fall	within	the	following	RTOs	and	ISOs :

NEER	competes	in	different	regions	to	differing	degrees,	but	in	general	it	seeks	to	enter	into	long-term	bilateral	contracts	for	the full	output	of	its	generation	facilities.	At	December	31,	2023,	approximately	94%	of	NEER's	net	generating	capacity	was	committed	under long-term	contracts.	Where	long-term	contracts	are	not	in	effect,	NEER	sells	the	output	of	its	facilities	into	daily	spot	markets.	In such	cases,	NEER	will	frequently	enter	into	shorter	term	bilateral	contracts,	typically	of	less	than	three	years	duration,	to	hedge	the price	risk	associated	with	selling	into	a	daily	spot	market.	Such	bilateral	contracts,	which	may	be	hedges	either	for	physical	delivery or	for	financial	(pricing)	offset,	serve	to	protect	a	portion	of	the	revenue	that	NEER	expects	to	derive	from	the	associated	generation facility.	Contracts	that	serve	the	economic	purpose	of	hedging	some	portion	of	the	expected	revenue	of	a	generation	facility	but	are	not recorded	as	hedges	under	GAAP	are	referred	to	as	'non-qualifying	hedges'	for	adjusted	earnings	purposes.	See	Management's	Discussion	Overview	-	Adjusted	Earnings.

Certain	 facilities	 within	 the	 NEER	 wind	 and	 solar	 generation	 portfolio	 produce	 RECs	 and	 other	 environmental	 attributes	 which	 are typically	sold	along	with	the	energy	from	the	plants	under	long-term	contracts,	or	may	be	sold	separately	from	wind	and	solar	generation not	sold	under	long-term	contracts.	The	purchasing	party	is	solely	entitled	to	the	reporting	rights	and	ownership	of	the	environmental attributes.

While	the	majority	of	NEER's	revenue	is	derived	from	the	output	of	its	generation	facilities,	NEER	is	also	an	active	competitor	in several	 regions	 in	 the	 wholesale	 full	 requirements	 business	 and	 in	 providing	 structured	 and	 customized	 power	 and	 fuel	 products	 and services	to	a	variety	of	customers.	In	the	full	requirements	service,	typically,	the	supplier	agrees	to	meet	the	customer's	needs	for	a full	range	of	products	for	every	hour	of	the	day,	at	a	fixed	price,	for	a	predetermined	period	of	time,	thereby	assuming	the	risk	of fluctuations	in	the	customer's	volume	requirements.

Expanded	competition	in	a	frequently	changing	regulatory	environment	presents	both	opportunities	and	risks	for	NEER.	Opportunities	exist for	the	selective	acquisition	of	generation	assets	and	for	the	construction	and	operation	of	efficient	facilities	that	can	sell	power	in competitive	markets.	NEER	seeks	to	reduce	its	market	risk	by	having	a	diversified	portfolio	by	fuel	type	and	location,	as	well	as	by contracting	for	the	future	sale	of	a	significant	amount	of	the	electricity	output	of	its	facilities.

NEER competes in different regions to differing degrees, but in general it seeks to enter into long-term bilateral contracts for the full output of its generation facilities. At December 31, 2021, approximately 92% of NEER's net generating capacity was committed under long-term contracts. Where long-term contracts are not in effect, NEER sells the output of its facilities into daily spot markets. In such cases, NEER will frequently enter into shorter term bilateral contracts, typically of less than three years duration, to hedge the price risk associated with selling into a daily spot market. Such bilateral contracts, which may be hedges either for physical delivery or for financial (pricing) offset, serve to protect a portion of the revenue that NEER expects to derive from the associated generation facility. Contracts that serve the economic purpose of hedging some portion of the expected revenue of a generation facility but are not recorded as hedges under GAAP are referred to as 'non-qualifying hedges' for adjusted earnings purposes. See Management's Discussion - Overview - Adjusted Earnings.

Certain facilities within the NEER wind and solar generation portfolio produce RECs and other environmental attributes which are typically sold along with the energy from the plants under long-term contracts, or may be sold separately from wind and solar generation not sold under longterm contracts. The purchasing party is solely entitled to the reporting rights and ownership of the environmental attributes.

While the majority of NEER's revenue is derived from the output of its generation facilities, NEER is also an active competitor in several regions in the  wholesale  full  requirements  business  and  in  providing  structured  and  customized  power  and  fuel  products  and  services  to  a  variety  of customers. In the full requirements service, typically, the supplier agrees to meet the customer's needs for a full range of products for every hour of the day, at a fixed price, for a predetermined period of time, thereby assuming the risk of fluctuations in the customer's volume requirements.

Expanded competition in a frequently changing regulatory environment presents both opportunities and risks for NEER. Opportunities exist for the  selective  acquisition  of  generation  assets  and  for  the  construction  and  operation  of  efficient  facilities  that  can  sell  power  in  competitive markets. NEER seeks to reduce its market risk by having a diversified portfolio by fuel type and location, as well as by contracting for the future sale of a significant amount of the electricity output of its facilities.

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy's fair value exposure related to FPL Cost Recovery Clauses evolve from 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of total fair value contributions and the shift between significant other observable inputs and significant unobservable inputs?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, NextEra Energy's fair value exposure tied to FPL Cost Recovery Clauses showed a notable evolution. In 2022, the total fair value was $1 million, with a negligible contribution from significant other observable inputs (-$5 million) and a small positive contribution from significant unobservable inputs (+$6 million). By 2023, the total fair value increased to $12 million, driven primarily by a -$12 million contribution from significant other observable inputs and a +$24 million contribution from significant unobservable inputs. In 2024, the fair value exposure rose sharply to $38 million, with significant other observable inputs contributing +$4 million and significant unobservable inputs contributing +$34 million. This indicates a growing reliance on unobservable inputs and a strengthening fair value position tied to FPL Cost Recovery Clauses over the three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2023) → [FPL Cost Recovery Assets]: In 2023, the total fair value exposure was $12 million, with -$12 million from significant other observable inputs and +$24 million from significant unobservable inputs.

Hop 2: [NEE](2024) → [FPL Cost Recovery Assets]: In 2024, the total fair value exposure rose to $38 million, with +$4 million from significant other observable inputs and +$34 million from significant unobservable inputs.

Hop 3: [NEE](2022) → [FPL Cost Recovery Assets]: In 2022, the total fair value exposure was $1 million, with -$5 million from significant other observable inputs and +$6 million from significant unobservable inputs.

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy's (NEE) special use funds evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this 3-year trend reveal about the company's investment strategy in restricted financial assets?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, NextEra Energy's special use funds increased steadily, reflecting a growing allocation to restricted financial assets. In 2022, NEE reported $8,698 million in special use funds. This amount rose to $9,800 million by 2024, indicating a consistent upward trend in the company's investment in these funds. The growth suggests a strategic emphasis on maintaining liquidity buffers or funding future obligations through restricted investments, particularly debt and equity securities, either directly or through commingled funds. This evolution aligns with NEE’s broader financial strategy of managing risk and ensuring capital availability for infrastructure and operational needs.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2023) → [Special Use Funds]: NEE disclosed holding primarily debt and equity securities in special use funds, with fair value determined through quoted market prices and commingled funds derived from underlying securities.
Hop 2: [NEE](2024) → [Special Use Funds]: Special use funds increased to $9,800 million from $8,698 million in the prior year, indicating a growing allocation to these restricted financial assets.

Hop 3: [NEE](2022) → [Special Use Funds]: NEE reported $8,698 million in special use funds, primarily invested in debt and equity securities, directly or through commingled funds, with fair value derived from quoted prices in active markets of underlying securities.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table	of	Contents

## NOTES	TO	CONSOLIDATED	FINANCIAL	STATEMENTS	(Continued)

respectively.	In	January	2024,	NEECH	reduced	the	net	notional	amount	of	its	interest	rate	contracts	by	$4.0	billion	as	a	result	of	the issuance	of	fixed-rate	debentures	at	NEECH	(see	Note	13).

Credit-Risk-Related	 Contingent	 Features -	 Certain	 derivative	 instruments	 contain	 credit-risk-related	 contingent	 features	 including, among	other	things,	the	requirement	to	maintain	an	investment	grade	credit	rating	from	specified	credit	rating	agencies	and	certain financial	 ratios,	 as	 well	 as	 credit-related	 cross-default	 and	 material	 adverse	 change	 triggers.	 At	 December	 31,	 2023	 and	 2022,	 the aggregate	fair	value	of	NEE's	derivative	instruments	with	credit-risk-related	contingent	features	that	were	in	a	liability	position	was approximately	$4.7	billion	($14	million	for	FPL)	and	$7.4	billion	($15	million	for	FPL),	respectively.

If	 the	 credit-risk-related	 contingent	 features	 underlying	 these	 derivative	 agreements	 were	 triggered,	 certain	 subsidiaries	 of	 NEE, including	FPL,	could	be	required	to	post	collateral	or	settle	contracts	according	to	contractual	terms	which	generally	allow	netting	of contracts	in	offsetting	positions.	Certain	derivative	contracts	contain	multiple	types	of	credit-related	triggers.	To	the	extent	these contracts	 contain	 a	 credit	 ratings	 downgrade	 trigger,	 the	 maximum	 exposure	 is	 included	 in	 the	 following	 credit	 ratings	 collateral posting	requirements.	If	FPL's	and	NEECH's	credit	ratings	were	downgraded	to	BBB/Baa2	(a	three	level	downgrade	for	FPL	and	a	one	level downgrade	for	NEECH	from	the	current	lowest	applicable	rating),	applicable	NEE	subsidiaries	would	be	required	to	post	collateral	such that	the	total	posted	collateral	would	be	approximately	$510	million	(none	at	FPL)	and	$1,625	million	(none	at	FPL)	at	December	31,	2023 and	2022,	respectively.	If	FPL's	and	NEECH's	credit	ratings	were	downgraded	to	below	investment	grade,	applicable	NEE	subsidiaries	would be	required	to	post	additional	collateral	such	that	the	total	posted	collateral	would	be	approximately	$2.4	billion	($15	million	at	FPL) and	$5.2	billion	($20	million	at	FPL)	at	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	respectively.	Some	derivative	contracts	do	not	contain	credit ratings	downgrade	triggers,	but	do	contain	provisions	that	require	certain	financial	measures	be	maintained	and/or	have	credit-related cross-default	triggers.	In	the	event	these	provisions	were	triggered,	applicable	NEE	subsidiaries	could	be	required	to	post	additional collateral	of	up	to	approximately	$1.7	billion	($50	million	at	FPL)	and	$1.1	billion	($185	million	at	FPL)	at	December	31,	2023	and 2022,	respectively.

Collateral	 related	 to	 derivatives,	 including	 amounts	 posted	 for	 margin,	 current	 exposures	 and	 future	 performance	 with	 exchanges	 and independent	system	operators,	may	be	posted	in	the	form	of	cash	or	credit	support	in	the	normal	course	of	business.	At	December	31,	2023 and	 2022,	 applicable	 NEE	 subsidiaries	 have	 posted	 approximately	 $691	 million	 (none	 at	 FPL)	 and	 $1,813	 million	 (none	 at	 FPL), respectively,	in	cash	and	$1,595	million	(none	at	FPL)	and	$2,806	million	(none	at	FPL),	respectively,	in	the	form	of	letters	of	credit and	surety	bonds	each	of	which	could	be	applied	toward	the	collateral	requirements	described	above.	FPL	and	NEECH	have	capacity	under their	credit	facilities	generally	in	excess	of	the	collateral	requirements	described	above	that	would	be	available	to	support,	among other	 things,	 derivative	 activities.	 Under	 the	 terms	 of	 the	 credit	 facilities,	 maintenance	 of	 a	 specific	 credit	 rating	 is	 not	 a condition	to	drawing	on	these	credit	facilities,	although	there	are	other	conditions	to	drawing	on	these	credit	facilities.

Additionally,	some	contracts	contain	certain	adequate	assurance	provisions	whereby	a	counterparty	may	demand	additional	collateral	based on	subjective	events	and/or	conditions.	Due	to	the	subjective	nature	of	these	provisions,	NEE	and	FPL	are	unable	to	determine	an	exact value	for	these	items	and	they	are	not	included	in	any	of	the	quantitative	disclosures	above.

## 4.	Non-Derivative	Fair	Value	Measurements

Non-derivative	fair	value	measurements	consist	of	NEE's	and	FPL's	cash	equivalents	and	restricted	cash	equivalents,	special	use	funds and	other	investments.	The	fair	value	of	these	financial	assets	is	determined	by	using	the	valuation	techniques	and	inputs	as	described in	Note	3	-	Fair	Value	Measurements	of	Derivative	Instruments	as	well	as	below.

Cash	Equivalents and	Restricted	Cash	Equivalents -	NEE	and	FPL	hold	investments	in	money	market	funds.	The	fair	value	of	these	funds	is estimated	using	a	market	approach	based	on	current	observable	market	prices.

Special	Use	Funds	and	Other	Investments -	NEE	and	FPL	hold	primarily	debt	and	equity	securities	directly,	as	well	as	indirectly	through commingled	funds.	Substantially	all	directly	held	equity	securities	are	valued	at	their	quoted	market	prices.	For	directly	held	debt securities,	 multiple	 prices	 and	 price	 types	 are	 obtained	 from	 pricing	 vendors	 whenever	 possible,	 which	 enables	 cross-provider validations.	A	primary	price	source	is	identified	based	on	asset	type,	class	or	issue	of	each	security.	Commingled	funds,	which	are similar	to	mutual	funds,	are	maintained	by	banks	or	investment	companies	and	hold	certain	investments	in	accordance	with	a	stated	set	of objectives.	 The	 fair	 value	 of	 commingled	 funds	 is	 primarily	 derived	 from	 the	 quoted	 prices	 in	 active	 markets	 of	 the	 underlying securities.	Because	the	fund	shares	are	offered	to	a	limited	group	of	investors,	they	are	not	considered	to	be	traded	in	an	active market.

Fair	Value	Measurement	Alternative -NEE	holds	investments	in	equity	securities	without	readily	determinable	fair	values,	which	are initially	recorded	at	cost,	of	approximately	$538	million	and	$485	million	at	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	respectively,	and	are	included in	noncurrent	other	assets	on	NEE's	consolidated	balance	sheets.	Adjustments	to	carrying	values	are	recorded	as	a	result	of	observable price	changes	in	transactions	for	identical	or	similar	investments	of	the	same	issuer.

Recurring	 Non-Derivative	 Fair	 Value	 Measurements -	 NEE's	 and	 FPL's	 financial	 assets	 and	 other	 fair	 value	 measurements	 made	 on	 a recurring	basis	by	fair	value	hierarchy	level	are	as	follows:

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
At December 31, 2021 and 2020, NEE had interest rate contracts with a notional amount of approximately $11.2 billion and a net notional amount of approximately $10.5 billion, respectively, and foreign currency contracts with a notional amount of approximately $1.0 billion and $1.0 billion, respectively.

Credit-Risk-Related Contingent Features - Certain derivative instruments contain credit-risk-related contingent features including, among other things, the requirement to maintain an investment grade credit rating from specified credit rating agencies and certain financial ratios, as well as credit-related cross-default and material adverse change triggers. At December 31, 2021 and 2020, the aggregate fair value of NEE's derivative instruments with credit-risk-related contingent features that were in a liability position was approximately $4.1 billion ($12 million for FPL) and $1.9 billion ($3 million for FPL), respectively.

If  the credit-risk-related contingent features underlying these derivative agreements were triggered, certain subsidiaries of NEE, including FPL, could  be  required  to  post  collateral  or  settle  contracts  according  to  contractual  terms  which  generally  allow  netting  of  contracts  in  offsetting positions.  Certain  derivative  contracts  contain  multiple  types  of  credit-related  triggers.  To  the  extent  these  contracts  contain  a  credit  ratings downgrade trigger, the maximum exposure is included in the following credit ratings collateral posting requirements. If FPL's and NEECH's credit ratings  were  downgraded  to  BBB/Baa2  (a  three  level  downgrade  for  FPL  and  a  one  level  downgrade  for  NEECH  from  the  current  lowest applicable rating), applicable NEE subsidiaries would be required to post collateral such that the total posted collateral would be approximately $645 million (none at FPL) and $80 million (none at FPL) at December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively. If FPL's and NEECH's credit ratings were downgraded to below investment grade, applicable NEE subsidiaries would be required to post additional collateral such that the total posted collateral  would  be  approximately  $2.7  billion  ($35  million  at  FPL)  and  $1.2  billion  ($75  million  at  FPL)  at  December  31,  2021  and  2020, respectively. Some derivative contracts do not contain credit ratings downgrade triggers, but do contain provisions that require certain financial measures  be  maintained  and/or  have  credit-related  cross-default  triggers.  In  the  event  these  provisions  were  triggered,  applicable  NEE subsidiaries  could  be  required  to  post  additional  collateral  of  up  to  approximately  $1,040  million  ($145  million  at  FPL)  and  $880  million  ($75 million at FPL) at December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

Collateral related to derivatives may be posted in the form of cash or credit support in the normal course of business. At December 31, 2021 and 2020, applicable NEE subsidiaries have posted approximately $84 million (none at FPL) and $2 million (none at FPL), respectively, in cash and $1,060 million (none at FPL) and $66 million (none at FPL), respectively, in the form of letters of credit each of which could be applied toward the collateral  requirements  described  above.  FPL  and  NEECH  have  capacity  under  their  credit  facilities  generally  in  excess  of  the  collateral requirements described above that would be available to support, among other things, derivative activities. Under the terms of the credit facilities, maintenance of a specific credit rating is not a condition to drawing on these credit facilities, although there are other conditions to drawing on these credit facilities.

Additionally, some contracts contain certain adequate assurance provisions whereby a counterparty may demand additional collateral based on subjective events and/or conditions. Due to the subjective nature of these provisions, NEE and FPL are unable to determine an exact value for these items and they are not included in any of the quantitative disclosures above.

## 4. Non-Derivative Fair Value Measurements

Non-derivative fair value measurements consist of NEE's and FPL's cash equivalents and restricted cash equivalents, special use funds and other investments. The fair value of these financial assets is determined by using the valuation techniques and inputs as described in Note 3 Fair Value Measurements of Derivative Instruments as well as below.

Cash Equivalents and Restricted Cash Equivalents - NEE and FPL hold investments in money market funds. The fair value of these funds is estimated using a market approach based on current observable market prices.

Special  Use  Funds  and  Other  Investments -  NEE  and  FPL  hold  primarily  debt  and  equity  securities  directly,  as  well  as  indirectly  through commingled funds.  Substantially  all  directly  held  equity  securities  are  valued  at  their  quoted  market  prices.  For  directly  held  debt  securities, multiple prices and price types are obtained from pricing vendors whenever possible, which enables cross-provider validations. A primary price source is identified based on asset type, class or issue of each security. Commingled funds, which are similar to mutual funds, are maintained by banks or investment companies and hold certain investments in accordance with a stated set of objectives. The fair value of commingled funds is primarily derived from the quoted prices in active markets of the underlying securities. Because the fund shares are offered to a limited group of investors, they are not considered to be traded in an active market.

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy's exposure to gas-related options evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does the shift in fair value and implied volatility reveal about the company's risk positioning in gas markets over time?
questions.answer: In 2022, NextEra Energy reported a fair value of $356 million in assets and $347 million in liabilities for options primarily tied to gas, with implied volatilities averaging 36%. By 2023, the fair value of these options dropped significantly to $100 million in assets and $97 million in liabilities, while implied volatilities increased to an average of 50%. In 2024, the fair value of gas-related options remained at $100 million in assets but slightly exceeded liabilities at $102 million, with implied volatilities decreasing to 52%. This trajectory shows a sharp reduction in exposure from 2022 to 2023, followed by stabilization, while volatility expectations increased and then slightly moderated, suggesting a strategic de-risking in gas options with a cautious outlook on price variability.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2022) → [Options - Primarily Gas]: Fair value of $356M (assets) and $347M (liabilities), implied volatility avg 36%
Hop 2: [NEE](2023) → [Options - Primarily Gas]: Fair value dropped to $100M (assets) and $97M (liabilities), implied volatility avg 50%
Hop 3: [NEE](2024) → [Options - Primarily Gas]: Fair value stabilized at $100M (assets) and $102M (liabilities), implied volatility slightly decreased to 52%

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy's net exposure to forward contracts for gas evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend suggest about the company's risk positioning in natural gas markets?
questions.answer: NextEra Energy's net exposure to forward contracts for gas was $160 million in 2022 (assets of $191 million and liabilities of $31 million), decreased to $300 million in 2023 (assets of $377 million and liabilities of $77 million), and then declined to $250 million in 2024 (assets of $296 million and liabilities of $46 million). This trend indicates a general reduction in net exposure from 2023 to 2024, suggesting a more cautious stance or rebalancing in natural gas market commitments after a period of increased forward contracting.

Hop 2: [NEE](2023) → Forward Contracts - Gas: Assets of $377 million and liabilities of $77 million, resulting in a net exposure of $300 million.
Hop 3: [NEE](2024) → Forward Contracts - Gas: Assets of $296 million and liabilities of $46 million, resulting in a net exposure of $250 million.

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy Resources' (NEER) reliance on long-term bilateral contracts for its net generating capacity evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend indicate about its risk management strategy in a volatile energy market?
questions.answer: NextEra Energy Resources (NEER) demonstrated a consistent and slightly increasing reliance on long-term bilateral contracts for its net generating capacity over the three-year period. In 2022, approximately 92% of NEER’s net generating capacity was committed under long-term contracts. This figure increased to 94% by the end of 2023 and remained steady at 94% in 2024. This trend indicates a strategic emphasis on revenue stability and risk mitigation by locking in long-term commitments, especially in a volatile energy market with fluctuating demand and pricing. The consistent use of these contracts, along with the use of non-qualifying hedges to protect expected revenues, reflects a disciplined approach to managing market risk.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2022) → [Long-Term Bilateral Contracts]: At the end of 2022, 92% of NEER's net generating capacity was under long-term contracts.
Hop 2: [NEE](2023) → [Long-Term Bilateral Contracts]: By December 31, 2023, NEER had increased its long-term contract coverage to 94% of net generating capacity.
Hop 3: [NEE](2024) → [Long-Term Bilateral Contracts]: In 2024, NEER maintained 94% of its net generating capacity under long-term contracts, showing continued strategic use of these agreements.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
NEER competes in different regions to differing degrees, but in general it seeks to enter into long-term bilateral contracts for the full output of its generation facilities. At December 31, 2021, approximately 92% of NEER's net generating capacity was committed under long-term contracts. Where long-term contracts are not in effect, NEER sells the output of its facilities into daily spot markets. In such cases, NEER will frequently enter into shorter term bilateral contracts, typically of less than three years duration, to hedge the price risk associated with selling into a daily spot market. Such bilateral contracts, which may be hedges either for physical delivery or for financial (pricing) offset, serve to protect a portion of the revenue that NEER expects to derive from the associated generation facility. Contracts that serve the economic purpose of hedging some portion of the expected revenue of a generation facility but are not recorded as hedges under GAAP are referred to as 'non-qualifying hedges' for adjusted earnings purposes. See Management's Discussion - Overview - Adjusted Earnings.

Certain facilities within the NEER wind and solar generation portfolio produce RECs and other environmental attributes which are typically sold along with the energy from the plants under long-term contracts, or may be sold separately from wind and solar generation not sold under longterm contracts. The purchasing party is solely entitled to the reporting rights and ownership of the environmental attributes.

While the majority of NEER's revenue is derived from the output of its generation facilities, NEER is also an active competitor in several regions in the  wholesale  full  requirements  business  and  in  providing  structured  and  customized  power  and  fuel  products  and  services  to  a  variety  of customers. In the full requirements service, typically, the supplier agrees to meet the customer's needs for a full range of products for every hour of the day, at a fixed price, for a predetermined period of time, thereby assuming the risk of fluctuations in the customer's volume requirements.

Expanded competition in a frequently changing regulatory environment presents both opportunities and risks for NEER. Opportunities exist for the  selective  acquisition  of  generation  assets  and  for  the  construction  and  operation  of  efficient  facilities  that  can  sell  power  in  competitive markets. NEER seeks to reduce its market risk by having a diversified portfolio by fuel type and location, as well as by contracting for the future sale of a significant amount of the electricity output of its facilities.

questions.question: How has NextEra Energy's exposure to estimation uncertainty in FPL Cost Recovery Clauses evolved from 2022 to 2024, based on the changing mix of observable and unobservable valuation inputs across these years?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, NextEra Energy's valuation of FPL Cost Recovery Clauses shifted significantly toward greater reliance on unobservable inputs, indicating increased estimation uncertainty. In 2022, the total fair value was $1 million, with $6 million in significant unobservable inputs offsetting -$5 million in significant other observable inputs. By 2023, the total fair value rose to $12 million, driven by a growing dominance of unobservable inputs at $24 million, compared to -$12 million in observable inputs. In 2024, the trend continued, with unobservable inputs reaching $34 million and total fair value at $38 million, while observable inputs remained minimal at $4 million. This progression shows a consistent increase in reliance on unobservable inputs, signaling rising complexity and potential risk in valuing these clauses.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2022) → [FPL Cost Recovery Assets]: Fair value of $1 million, with -$5 million in significant other observable inputs and $6 million in significant unobservable inputs.
Hop 2: [NEE](2023) → [FPL Cost Recovery Assets]: Fair value increased to $12 million, with -$12 million in significant other observable inputs and $24 million in significant unobservable inputs.
Hop 3: [NEE](2024) → [FPL Cost Recovery Assets]: Fair value reached $38 million, with $4 million in significant other observable inputs and $34 million in significant unobservable inputs.

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy's (NEE) exposure to Special Use Funds evolve from 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of fair value disclosures, collateral implications, and balance sheet presentation?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, NextEra Energy's exposure to Special Use Funds showed a clear upward trend in fair value and evolved in its balance sheet presentation. In 2022, NEE disclosed that Special Use Funds were primarily composed of debt and equity securities, with fair values determined using quoted market prices for equities and pricing vendor inputs for debt securities. By 2023, NEE provided additional detail, noting that commingled funds' fair values were derived from quoted prices of underlying securities and introduced a new category of equity investments without readily determinable fair values, which grew from $485 million in 2022 to $538 million in 2023. In 2024, Special Use Funds were explicitly listed on the balance sheet at $9,800 million as of December 31, 2024, up from $8,698 million in 2023, indicating a $1,102 million increase. This progression shows NEE not only increased its holdings in these funds but also enhanced transparency in reporting their valuation and risk exposure, particularly in derivative-related collateral requirements.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: NEE(2022) → Special Use Funds: Disclosed fair value methodology for Special Use Funds, including equity and debt securities, and indirect holdings through commingled funds.
Hop 2: NEE(2023) → Special Use Funds: Expanded disclosure to include equity investments without readily determinable fair values, totaling $485 million in 2022 and $538 million in 2023.
Hop 3: NEE(2024) → Special Use Funds: Explicitly reported Special Use Funds on the balance sheet at $9,800 million, up from $8,698 million in 2023.

At December 31, 2021 and 2020, NEE had interest rate contracts with a notional amount of approximately $11.2 billion and a net notional amount of approximately $10.5 billion, respectively, and foreign currency contracts with a notional amount of approximately $1.0 billion and $1.0 billion, respectively.

Credit-Risk-Related Contingent Features - Certain derivative instruments contain credit-risk-related contingent features including, among other things, the requirement to maintain an investment grade credit rating from specified credit rating agencies and certain financial ratios, as well as credit-related cross-default and material adverse change triggers. At December 31, 2021 and 2020, the aggregate fair value of NEE's derivative instruments with credit-risk-related contingent features that were in a liability position was approximately $4.1 billion ($12 million for FPL) and $1.9 billion ($3 million for FPL), respectively.

If  the credit-risk-related contingent features underlying these derivative agreements were triggered, certain subsidiaries of NEE, including FPL, could  be  required  to  post  collateral  or  settle  contracts  according  to  contractual  terms  which  generally  allow  netting  of  contracts  in  offsetting positions.  Certain  derivative  contracts  contain  multiple  types  of  credit-related  triggers.  To  the  extent  these  contracts  contain  a  credit  ratings downgrade trigger, the maximum exposure is included in the following credit ratings collateral posting requirements. If FPL's and NEECH's credit ratings  were  downgraded  to  BBB/Baa2  (a  three  level  downgrade  for  FPL  and  a  one  level  downgrade  for  NEECH  from  the  current  lowest applicable rating), applicable NEE subsidiaries would be required to post collateral such that the total posted collateral would be approximately $645 million (none at FPL) and $80 million (none at FPL) at December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively. If FPL's and NEECH's credit ratings were downgraded to below investment grade, applicable NEE subsidiaries would be required to post additional collateral such that the total posted collateral  would  be  approximately  $2.7  billion  ($35  million  at  FPL)  and  $1.2  billion  ($75  million  at  FPL)  at  December  31,  2021  and  2020, respectively. Some derivative contracts do not contain credit ratings downgrade triggers, but do contain provisions that require certain financial measures  be  maintained  and/or  have  credit-related  cross-default  triggers.  In  the  event  these  provisions  were  triggered,  applicable  NEE subsidiaries  could  be  required  to  post  additional  collateral  of  up  to  approximately  $1,040  million  ($145  million  at  FPL)  and  $880  million  ($75 million at FPL) at December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

Collateral related to derivatives may be posted in the form of cash or credit support in the normal course of business. At December 31, 2021 and 2020, applicable NEE subsidiaries have posted approximately $84 million (none at FPL) and $2 million (none at FPL), respectively, in cash and $1,060 million (none at FPL) and $66 million (none at FPL), respectively, in the form of letters of credit each of which could be applied toward the collateral  requirements  described  above.  FPL  and  NEECH  have  capacity  under  their  credit  facilities  generally  in  excess  of  the  collateral requirements described above that would be available to support, among other things, derivative activities. Under the terms of the credit facilities, maintenance of a specific credit rating is not a condition to drawing on these credit facilities, although there are other conditions to drawing on these credit facilities.

Additionally, some contracts contain certain adequate assurance provisions whereby a counterparty may demand additional collateral based on subjective events and/or conditions. Due to the subjective nature of these provisions, NEE and FPL are unable to determine an exact value for these items and they are not included in any of the quantitative disclosures above.

## 4. Non-Derivative Fair Value Measurements

Non-derivative fair value measurements consist of NEE's and FPL's cash equivalents and restricted cash equivalents, special use funds and other investments. The fair value of these financial assets is determined by using the valuation techniques and inputs as described in Note 3 Fair Value Measurements of Derivative Instruments as well as below.

Cash Equivalents and Restricted Cash Equivalents - NEE and FPL hold investments in money market funds. The fair value of these funds is estimated using a market approach based on current observable market prices.

Special  Use  Funds  and  Other  Investments -  NEE  and  FPL  hold  primarily  debt  and  equity  securities  directly,  as  well  as  indirectly  through commingled funds.  Substantially  all  directly  held  equity  securities  are  valued  at  their  quoted  market  prices.  For  directly  held  debt  securities, multiple prices and price types are obtained from pricing vendors whenever possible, which enables cross-provider validations. A primary price source is identified based on asset type, class or issue of each security. Commingled funds, which are similar to mutual funds, are maintained by banks or investment companies and hold certain investments in accordance with a stated set of objectives. The fair value of commingled funds is primarily derived from the quoted prices in active markets of the underlying securities. Because the fund shares are offered to a limited group of investors, they are not considered to be traded in an active market.

## 4.	Non-Derivative	Fair	Value	Measurements

Non-derivative	fair	value	measurements	consist	of	NEE's	and	FPL's	cash	equivalents	and	restricted	cash	equivalents,	special	use	funds and	other	investments.	The	fair	value	of	these	financial	assets	is	determined	by	using	the	valuation	techniques	and	inputs	as	described in	Note	3	-	Fair	Value	Measurements	of	Derivative	Instruments	as	well	as	below.

Cash	Equivalents and	Restricted	Cash	Equivalents -	NEE	and	FPL	hold	investments	in	money	market	funds.	The	fair	value	of	these	funds	is estimated	using	a	market	approach	based	on	current	observable	market	prices.

Special	Use	Funds	and	Other	Investments -	NEE	and	FPL	hold	primarily	debt	and	equity	securities	directly,	as	well	as	indirectly	through commingled	funds.	Substantially	all	directly	held	equity	securities	are	valued	at	their	quoted	market	prices.	For	directly	held	debt securities,	 multiple	 prices	 and	 price	 types	 are	 obtained	 from	 pricing	 vendors	 whenever	 possible,	 which	 enables	 cross-provider validations.	A	primary	price	source	is	identified	based	on	asset	type,	class	or	issue	of	each	security.	Commingled	funds,	which	are similar	to	mutual	funds,	are	maintained	by	banks	or	investment	companies	and	hold	certain	investments	in	accordance	with	a	stated	set	of objectives.	 The	 fair	 value	 of	 commingled	 funds	 is	 primarily	 derived	 from	 the	 quoted	 prices	 in	 active	 markets	 of	 the	 underlying securities.	Because	the	fund	shares	are	offered	to	a	limited	group	of	investors,	they	are	not	considered	to	be	traded	in	an	active market.

Fair	Value	Measurement	Alternative -NEE	holds	investments	in	equity	securities	without	readily	determinable	fair	values,	which	are initially	recorded	at	cost,	of	approximately	$538	million	and	$485	million	at	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	respectively,	and	are	included in	noncurrent	other	assets	on	NEE's	consolidated	balance	sheets.	Adjustments	to	carrying	values	are	recorded	as	a	result	of	observable price	changes	in	transactions	for	identical	or	similar	investments	of	the	same	issuer.

questions.question: How did Southern Company's funding and disclosure approach to its non-qualified defined benefits evolve from 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of pension contributions and tax-related uncertainties impacting benefit structures?
questions.answer: Southern Company consistently maintained that its qualified pension plan required no contributions for the years 2022, 2023, and 2024, with no mandatory contributions anticipated in the following year for each respective filing. The non-qualified defined benefits, which are funded on a cash basis for a select group of employees, remained unchanged in structure across the three years. However, in 2022, Southern Company referenced a 2019 state tax filing position that could reduce its effective tax rate if accepted, potentially impacting available funds for benefits. In 2023, a portion of the unrecognized tax benefits related to tax credit utilization was resolved due to statute of limitations expiration, which decreased the effective tax rate and may have influenced discretionary funding capacity. In 2024, new state tax filing positions were introduced that, if accepted, could further reduce the effective tax rate, potentially affecting future benefit structures or cash flow allocations. This shows a consistent pension funding policy, but with evolving tax-related uncertainties that could indirectly influence non-qualified benefit funding over time.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [SO](2022) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefits]: No contributions to qualified pension plan; non-qualified benefits funded on a cash basis; 2019 state tax filing position could reduce effective tax rate.

Hop 2: [SO](2023) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefits]: No contributions to qualified pension plan; non-qualified benefits still cash-funded; 2019 tax filing position resolved partially due to statute of limitations, decreasing effective tax rate.

Hop 3: [SO](2024) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefits]: No contributions to qualified pension plan; non-qualified benefits unchanged; new 2024 state tax filing position could reduce effective tax rate if accepted.

The unrecognized tax positions increase from prior periods for 2020 and the balance of unrecognized tax benefits at December 31, 2020 and 2021 primarily relate to a 2019 state tax filing position to exclude certain gains from 2019 dispositions from taxation in a certain unitary state. If accepted by the state, this position would decrease Southern Company's annual effective tax rate. The ultimate outcome of this unrecognized tax benefit is dependent on completion of the related state audit, which is not expected to be resolved within the next 12 months.

All of the Registrants classify interest on tax uncertainties as interest expense. Accrued interest for all tax positions was immaterial for all years presented. None of the Registrants accrued any penalties on uncertain tax positions.

The IRS has finalized its audits of Southern Company's consolidated federal income tax returns through 2020. Southern Company is a participant in the Compliance Assurance Process of the IRS. The audits for the Registrants' state income tax returns have either been concluded, or the statute of limitations has expired, for years prior to 2015.

## 11. RETIREMENT BENEFITS

The Southern Company system has a qualified defined benefit, trusteed pension plan covering substantially all employees, with the exception of PowerSecure employees. The qualified pension plan is funded in accordance with requirements of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended (ERISA). No contributions to the qualified pension plan were made for the year ended December 31, 2021 and no mandatory contributions to the qualified pension plan are anticipated for the year ending December 31, 2022. The Southern Company system also provides certain non-qualified defined benefits for a select group of management and highly compensated employees, which are funded on a cash basis. In addition, the Southern Company system provides certain medical care and life insurance benefits for retired employees through other postretirement benefit plans. The traditional electric operating companies fund other postretirement trusts to the extent required by their respective regulatory commissions. Southern Company Gas has a separate unfunded supplemental retirement health care plan that provides medical care and life insurance benefits to employees of discontinued businesses. For the year ending December 31, 2022, no contributions to any other postretirement trusts are expected.

questions.question: How did the treatment and reporting of scheduled payments under outdoor lighting contracts evolve across Southern Power's disclosures in 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this reveal about the growing materiality or structural importance of these contracts over time?
questions.answer: In 2022, Southern Power noted that the undiscounted cash flows from outdoor lighting contracts accounted for as operating leases at Mississippi Power were immaterial. By 2023, the company began including scheduled payments to be received under these contracts in maturity analyses alongside tolling arrangements and PPAs, signaling increased attention to their financial structure. In 2024, Southern Power explicitly integrated outdoor lighting contracts into its broader lease income reporting framework, presenting them alongside significant revenue-generating arrangements like PPAs. This progression indicates a growing materiality and structural integration of outdoor lighting contracts within Southern Power’s financial disclosures over the three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [SO](2022) → Outdoor Lighting Contracts: Undiscounted cash flows from these contracts were deemed immaterial in disclosures.
Hop 2: [SO](2023) → Outdoor Lighting Contracts: Scheduled payments began appearing in maturity analyses with other lease arrangements, indicating increased visibility.
Hop 3: [SO](2024) → Outdoor Lighting Contracts: Contracts were explicitly included in lease income reporting and presented alongside major revenue-generating agreements like PPAs.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text: Southern Power receives payments for renewable energy under PPAs accounted for as operating leases that are considered contingent rents and are therefore not reflected in the table above. Alabama Power and Southern Power allocate revenue to the nonlease components of PPAs based on the stand-alone selling price of capacity and energy. The undiscounted cash flows to be received under outdoor lighting contracts accounted for as operating leases at Mississippi Power are immaterial.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text: Lease payments received under tolling arrangements and PPAs consist of either scheduled payments or variable payments based on the amount of energy produced by the underlying electric generating units. Lease income related to PPAs is included in wholesale revenues for Alabama Power, Georgia Power, and Southern Power. questions.question: How did the asset retirement obligation (ARO) for Alabama Power's Plant Farley evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this 3-year progression indicate about the estimated decommissioning costs for the facility?
questions.answer: The ARO for Alabama Power's Plant Farley increased from $1,324 million in 2022 to $1,385 million in 2024, with a reported value of $1,259 million in 2023. This reflects a general upward trend in the estimated decommissioning liability, suggesting rising projected costs or adjustments in present-value calculations over time.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [SO](2023) → [Plant Farley]: Discloses that Alabama Power has retirement obligations related to Plant Farley under asset retirement obligations (AROs), with $1,259 million listed in 2023.
Hop 2: [SO](2024) → [Plant Farley]: Reports an increase in the ARO for Plant Farley to $1,385 million in 2024, up from $1,259 million in 2023.
Hop 3: [SO](2022) → [Plant Farley]: Indicates the ARO for Plant Farley was $1,324 million in 2022, showing that the liability was already rising prior to 2023.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## COMBINED	NOTES	TO	FINANCIAL	STATEMENTS

## 6.	ASSET	RETIREMENT	OBLIGATIONS

AROs	are	computed	as	the	present	value	of	the	estimated	costs	for	an	asset's	future	retirement	and	are	recorded	in	the	period in	which	the	liability	is	incurred.	The	estimated	costs	are	capitalized	as	part	of	the	related	long-lived	asset	and depreciated	over	the	asset's	useful	life.	In	the	absence	of	quoted	market	prices,	AROs	are	estimated	using	present	value techniques	in	which	estimates	of	future	cash	outlays	associated	with	the	asset	retirements	are	discounted	using	a	creditadjusted	risk-free	rate.	Estimates	of	the	timing	and	amounts	of	future	cash	outlays	are	based	on	projections	of	when	and	how the	assets	will	be	retired	and	the	cost	of	future	removal	activities.	Each	traditional	electric	operating	company	and	natural gas	distribution	utility	has	received	accounting	guidance	from	its	state	PSC	or	applicable	state	regulatory	agency	allowing the	continued	accrual	or	recovery	of	other	retirement	costs	for	long-lived	assets	that	it	does	not	have	a	legal	obligation	to retire.	Accordingly,	the	accumulated	removal	costs	for	these	obligations	are	reflected	in	the	balance	sheets	as	regulatory liabilities	and	amounts	to	be	recovered	are	reflected	in	the	balance	sheets	as	regulatory	assets.

The	ARO	liabilities	for	the	traditional	electric	operating	companies	primarily	relate	to	facilities	that	are	subject	to	the CCR	Rule	and	the	related	state	rules,	principally	ash	ponds.	In	addition,	Alabama	Power	and	Georgia	Power	have	retirement obligations	related	to	the	decommissioning	of	nuclear	facilities	(Alabama	Power's	Plant	Farley	and	Georgia	Power's	ownership interests	in	Plant	Hatch	and	Plant	Vogtle	Units	1	through	3).	See	"Nuclear	Decommissioning"	herein	for	additional information.	Other	significant	AROs	include	various	landfill	sites	and	asbestos	removal	for	Alabama	Power,	Georgia	Power,	and Mississippi	Power	and	gypsum	cells	and	mine	reclamation	for	Mississippi	Power.	The	ARO	liability	for	Southern	Power	primarily relates	to	its	solar	and	wind	facilities,	which	are	located	on	long-term	land	leases	requiring	the	restoration	of	land	at	the end	of	the	lease.

The	traditional	electric	operating	companies	and	Southern	Company	Gas	also	have	identified	other	retirement	obligations,	such as	obligations	related	to	certain	electric	transmission	and	distribution	facilities,	certain	asbestos-containing	material within	long-term	assets	not	subject	to	ongoing	repair	and	maintenance	activities,	certain	wireless	communication	towers,	the disposal	of	polychlorinated	biphenyls	in	certain	transformers,	leasehold	improvements,	equipment	on	customer	property,	and property	associated	with	the	Southern	Company	system's	rail	lines	and	natural	gas	pipelines.	However,	liabilities	for	the removal	of	these	assets	have	not	been	recorded	because	the	settlement	timing	for	certain	retirement	obligations	related	to these	assets	is	indeterminable	and,	therefore,	the	fair	value	of	the	retirement	obligations	cannot	be	reasonably	estimated.	A liability	for	these	retirement	obligations	will	be	recognized	when	sufficient	information	becomes	available	to	support	a reasonable	estimation	of	the	ARO.

Southern	Company	and	the	traditional	electric	operating	companies	will	continue	to	recognize	in	their	respective	statements of	income	allowed	removal	costs	in	accordance	with	regulatory	treatment.	Any	differences	between	costs	recognized	in accordance	with	accounting	standards	related	to	asset	retirement	and	environmental	obligations	and	those	reflected	in	rates are	recognized	as	either	a	regulatory	asset	or	liability	in	the	balance	sheets	as	ordered	by	the	various	state	PSCs.

Details	of	the	AROs	included	in	the	balance	sheets	are	as	follows:

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy's exposure to gas-related options evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does the multi-year trend in fair value and volatility assumptions reveal about the company's risk positioning in gas markets?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, NextEra Energy's fair value of gas-related options decreased from $356 million (assets) and $347 million (liabilities) in 2022, to $100 million (assets) and $97 million (liabilities) in 2023, and further to $100 million (assets) and $102 million (liabilities) in 2024. The implied volatility assumptions for these options also declined from 36% in 2022 to 50% in 2023 and then to 52% in 2024, indicating a reduction in expected market volatility and potentially a strategic de-risking in gas market exposure over the three-year period.

Hop 2: [NEE](2024) → [Options - Primarily Gas]: Fair value of $100 million (assets) and $102 million (liabilities) with implied volatility of 52%
Hop 3: [NEE](2023) → [Options - Primarily Gas]: Fair value of $100 million (assets) and $97 million (liabilities) with implied volatility of 50%

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy's exposure to gas forward contracts evolve from 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of fair value of assets and liabilities, and what does this 3-year progression indicate about the company's risk positioning in natural gas markets?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, NextEra Energy's fair value of gas forward contract assets increased from $191 million to $296 million, while liabilities rose more sharply from $31 million to $46 million. This indicates a growing but increasingly balanced exposure to natural gas markets, with a notable spike in 2023 where assets reached $377 million. The trend suggests a strategic expansion in gas market participation, accompanied by rising market risk.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2022) → [Forward Contracts - Gas]: Fair value of assets was $191 million and liabilities were $31 million as of December 31, 2021, indicating a relatively modest exposure to gas forward contracts.

Hop 2: [NEE](2023) → [Forward Contracts - Gas]: Assets surged to $377 million with liabilities at $77 million, showing a significant increase in exposure and risk, potentially reflecting market volatility or strategic positioning.

Hop 3: [NEE](2024) → [Forward Contracts - Gas]: Assets remained elevated at $296 million and liabilities increased slightly to $46 million, suggesting a partial retreat from peak 2023 levels but continued active participation in gas forward markets.

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy Resources' (NEER) reliance on long-term bilateral contracts evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does the progression in contracted net generating capacity percentages (92% in 2021, 94% in 2023, and 94% in 2024) indicate about its long-term risk management and revenue stabilization strategy?
questions.answer: From 2022 through 2024, NEER maintained a strong emphasis on long-term bilateral contracts as a core part of its revenue strategy. In 2022, it was reported that 92% of NEER's net generating capacity was committed under long-term contracts as of December 31, 2021. By December 31, 2023, this figure had increased to 94%, and it remained at 94% as of December 31, 2024. This trend indicates a consistent and slightly increasing preference for long-term contracts, which NEER uses to stabilize revenue and manage market risk, especially in volatile energy markets. The slight increase from 92% to 94% between 2021 and 2023, and the maintenance of that level into 2024, shows a strategic pivot toward greater revenue predictability and reduced exposure to daily spot market fluctuations.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2022) → [Long-Term Bilateral Contracts]: As of December 31, 2021, 92% of NEER's net generating capacity was under long-term contracts.
Hop 2: [NEE](2024) → [Long-Term Bilateral Contracts]: As of December 31, 2024, 94% of NEER's net generating capacity was committed under long-term contracts.
Hop 3: [NEE](2023) → [Long-Term Bilateral Contracts]: As of December 31, 2023, 94% of NEER's net generating capacity was under long-term contracts.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
NEER competes in different regions to differing degrees, but in general it seeks to enter into long-term bilateral contracts for the full output of its generation facilities. At December 31, 2021, approximately 92% of NEER's net generating capacity was committed under long-term contracts. Where long-term contracts are not in effect, NEER sells the output of its facilities into daily spot markets. In such cases, NEER will frequently enter into shorter term bilateral contracts, typically of less than three years duration, to hedge the price risk associated with selling into a daily spot market. Such bilateral contracts, which may be hedges either for physical delivery or for financial (pricing) offset, serve to protect a portion of the revenue that NEER expects to derive from the associated generation facility. Contracts that serve the economic purpose of hedging some portion of the expected revenue of a generation facility but are not recorded as hedges under GAAP are referred to as 'non-qualifying hedges' for adjusted earnings purposes. See Management's Discussion - Overview - Adjusted Earnings.

Certain facilities within the NEER wind and solar generation portfolio produce RECs and other environmental attributes which are typically sold along with the energy from the plants under long-term contracts, or may be sold separately from wind and solar generation not sold under longterm contracts. The purchasing party is solely entitled to the reporting rights and ownership of the environmental attributes.

While the majority of NEER's revenue is derived from the output of its generation facilities, NEER is also an active competitor in several regions in the  wholesale  full  requirements  business  and  in  providing  structured  and  customized  power  and  fuel  products  and  services  to  a  variety  of customers. In the full requirements service, typically, the supplier agrees to meet the customer's needs for a full range of products for every hour of the day, at a fixed price, for a predetermined period of time, thereby assuming the risk of fluctuations in the customer's volume requirements.

Expanded competition in a frequently changing regulatory environment presents both opportunities and risks for NEER. Opportunities exist for the  selective  acquisition  of  generation  assets  and  for  the  construction  and  operation  of  efficient  facilities  that  can  sell  power  in  competitive markets. NEER seeks to reduce its market risk by having a diversified portfolio by fuel type and location, as well as by contracting for the future sale of a significant amount of the electricity output of its facilities.

questions.question: How did NextEra Energy's fair value exposure related to FPL Cost Recovery Clauses evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this 3-year progression reveal about the company's valuation methodology and risk profile?
questions.answer: NextEra Energy's fair value exposure tied to FPL Cost Recovery Clauses shifted from a net positive $1 million in 2022, to a modest $12 million in 2023, and then increased significantly to $38 million in 2024. This trajectory shows a growing reliance on unobservable inputs, particularly in 2024 when unobservable inputs contributed $34 million to the total fair value, suggesting increased complexity and potential volatility in valuing these assets over time.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2022) → [FPL Cost Recovery Assets]: Fair value exposure was minimal at $1 million, with a mix of slightly negative observable inputs and small positive unobservable inputs (+$6 million unobservable inputs).

Hop 2: [NEE](2023) → [FPL Cost Recovery Assets]: Fair value increased to $12 million, driven primarily by unobservable inputs which contributed +$24 million, offsetting slightly negative observable inputs.

Hop 3: [NEE](2024) → [FPL Cost Recovery Assets]: Fair value jumped to $38 million, with unobservable inputs contributing $34 million, indicating a stronger dependence on internal modeling assumptions.

questions.question: What does the evolution of NextEra Energy's Special Use Funds from 2022 to 2024 reveal about the company's liquidity positioning in relation to its derivative-related collateral obligations across this period?
questions.answer: The company's Special Use Funds increased from $8,698 million in 2023 to $9,800 million in 2024, following detailed disclosures in 2022 about derivative-related collateral requirements that could reach up to $2.7 billion in the event of a credit downgrade. In 2023, collateral posting requirements in the event of a downgrade to below investment grade dropped significantly from $5.2 billion in 2022 to $2.4 billion in 2023, while actual collateral posted in cash increased to $691 million in 2023 from $84 million in 2022. This suggests the company strengthened its liquidity position through growth in Special Use Funds while simultaneously reducing its potential derivative-related collateral exposure, indicating a strategic improvement in risk management positioning.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [NEE](2022) → [Special Use Funds]: Discloses Special Use Funds as part of non-derivative fair value measurements and reveals potential derivative collateral requirements up to $2.7 billion in case of credit downgrade
Hop 2: [NEE](2023) → [Special Use Funds]: Reports $8,698 million in Special Use Funds while showing reduced potential collateral requirements of $2.4 billion following credit downgrade scenarios
Hop 3: [NEE](2024) → [Special Use Funds]: Reports increase in Special Use Funds to $9,800 million while maintaining stable derivative exposure levels from 2023

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
At December 31, 2021 and 2020, NEE had interest rate contracts with a notional amount of approximately $11.2 billion and a net notional amount of approximately $10.5 billion, respectively, and foreign currency contracts with a notional amount of approximately $1.0 billion and $1.0 billion, respectively.

Credit-Risk-Related Contingent Features - Certain derivative instruments contain credit-risk-related contingent features including, among other things, the requirement to maintain an investment grade credit rating from specified credit rating agencies and certain financial ratios, as well as credit-related cross-default and material adverse change triggers. At December 31, 2021 and 2020, the aggregate fair value of NEE's derivative instruments with credit-risk-related contingent features that were in a liability position was approximately $4.1 billion ($12 million for FPL) and $1.9 billion ($3 million for FPL), respectively.

If  the credit-risk-related contingent features underlying these derivative agreements were triggered, certain subsidiaries of NEE, including FPL, could  be  required  to  post  collateral  or  settle  contracts  according  to  contractual  terms  which  generally  allow  netting  of  contracts  in  offsetting positions.  Certain  derivative  contracts  contain  multiple  types  of  credit-related  triggers.  To  the  extent  these  contracts  contain  a  credit  ratings downgrade trigger, the maximum exposure is included in the following credit ratings collateral posting requirements. If FPL's and NEECH's credit ratings  were  downgraded  to  BBB/Baa2  (a  three  level  downgrade  for  FPL  and  a  one  level  downgrade  for  NEECH  from  the  current  lowest applicable rating), applicable NEE subsidiaries would be required to post collateral such that the total posted collateral would be approximately $645 million (none at FPL) and $80 million (none at FPL) at December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively. If FPL's and NEECH's credit ratings were downgraded to below investment grade, applicable NEE subsidiaries would be required to post additional collateral such that the total posted collateral  would  be  approximately  $2.7  billion  ($35  million  at  FPL)  and  $1.2  billion  ($75  million  at  FPL)  at  December  31,  2021  and  2020, respectively. Some derivative contracts do not contain credit ratings downgrade triggers, but do contain provisions that require certain financial measures  be  maintained  and/or  have  credit-related  cross-default  triggers.  In  the  event  these  provisions  were  triggered,  applicable  NEE subsidiaries  could  be  required  to  post  additional  collateral  of  up  to  approximately  $1,040  million  ($145  million  at  FPL)  and  $880  million  ($75 million at FPL) at December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

Collateral related to derivatives may be posted in the form of cash or credit support in the normal course of business. At December 31, 2021 and 2020, applicable NEE subsidiaries have posted approximately $84 million (none at FPL) and $2 million (none at FPL), respectively, in cash and $1,060 million (none at FPL) and $66 million (none at FPL), respectively, in the form of letters of credit each of which could be applied toward the collateral  requirements  described  above.  FPL  and  NEECH  have  capacity  under  their  credit  facilities  generally  in  excess  of  the  collateral requirements described above that would be available to support, among other things, derivative activities. Under the terms of the credit facilities, maintenance of a specific credit rating is not a condition to drawing on these credit facilities, although there are other conditions to drawing on these credit facilities.

Additionally, some contracts contain certain adequate assurance provisions whereby a counterparty may demand additional collateral based on subjective events and/or conditions. Due to the subjective nature of these provisions, NEE and FPL are unable to determine an exact value for these items and they are not included in any of the quantitative disclosures above.

## 4. Non-Derivative Fair Value Measurements

Non-derivative fair value measurements consist of NEE's and FPL's cash equivalents and restricted cash equivalents, special use funds and other investments. The fair value of these financial assets is determined by using the valuation techniques and inputs as described in Note 3 Fair Value Measurements of Derivative Instruments as well as below.

Cash Equivalents and Restricted Cash Equivalents - NEE and FPL hold investments in money market funds. The fair value of these funds is estimated using a market approach based on current observable market prices.

Special  Use  Funds  and  Other  Investments -  NEE  and  FPL  hold  primarily  debt  and  equity  securities  directly,  as  well  as  indirectly  through commingled funds.  Substantially  all  directly  held  equity  securities  are  valued  at  their  quoted  market  prices.  For  directly  held  debt  securities, multiple prices and price types are obtained from pricing vendors whenever possible, which enables cross-provider validations. A primary price source is identified based on asset type, class or issue of each security. Commingled funds, which are similar to mutual funds, are maintained by banks or investment companies and hold certain investments in accordance with a stated set of objectives. The fair value of commingled funds is primarily derived from the quoted prices in active markets of the underlying securities. Because the fund shares are offered to a limited group of investors, they are not considered to be traded in an active market.

Certain	derivative	contracts	contain	multiple	types	of	credit-related	triggers.	To	the	extent	these contracts	 contain	 a	 credit	 ratings	 downgrade	 trigger,	 the	 maximum	 exposure	 is	 included	 in	 the	 following	 credit	 ratings	 collateral posting	requirements.	If	FPL's	and	NEECH's	credit	ratings	were	downgraded	to	BBB/Baa2	(a	three	level	downgrade	for	FPL	and	a	one	level downgrade	for	NEECH	from	the	current	lowest	applicable	rating),	applicable	NEE	subsidiaries	would	be	required	to	post	collateral	such that	the	total	posted	collateral	would	be	approximately	$510	million	(none	at	FPL)	and	$1,625	million	(none	at	FPL)	at	December	31,	2023 and	2022,	respectively.	If	FPL's	and	NEECH's	credit	ratings	were	downgraded	to	below	investment	grade,	applicable	NEE	subsidiaries	would be	required	to	post	additional	collateral	such	that	the	total	posted	collateral	would	be	approximately	$2.4	billion	($15	million	at	FPL) and	$5.2	billion	($20	million	at	FPL)	at	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	respectively.	Some	derivative	contracts	do	not	contain	credit ratings	downgrade	triggers,	but	do	contain	provisions	that	require	certain	financial	measures	be	maintained	and/or	have	credit-related cross-default	triggers.	In	the	event	these	provisions	were	triggered,	applicable	NEE	subsidiaries	could	be	required	to	post	additional collateral	of	up	to	approximately	$1.7	billion	($50	million	at	FPL)	and	$1.1	billion	($185	million	at	FPL)	at	December	31,	2023	and 2022,	respectively.

Collateral	 related	 to	 derivatives,	 including	 amounts	 posted	 for	 margin,	 current	 exposures	 and	 future	 performance	 with	 exchanges	 and independent	system	operators,	may	be	posted	in	the	form	of	cash	or	credit	support	in	the	normal	course	of	business.	At	December	31,	2023 and	 2022,	 applicable	 NEE	 subsidiaries	 have	 posted	 approximately	 $691	 million	 (none	 at	 FPL)	 and	 $1,813	 million	 (none	 at	 FPL), respectively,	in	cash	and	$1,595	million	(none	at	FPL)	and	$2,806	million	(none	at	FPL),	respectively,	in	the	form	of	letters	of	credit and	surety	bonds	each	of	which	could	be	applied	toward	the	collateral	requirements	described	above.	FPL	and	NEECH	have	capacity	under their	credit	facilities	generally	in	excess	of	the	collateral	requirements	described	above	that	would	be	available	to	support,	among other	 things,	 derivative	 activities.	 Under	 the	 terms	 of	 the	 credit	 facilities,	 maintenance	 of	 a	 specific	 credit	 rating	 is	 not	 a condition	to	drawing	on	these	credit	facilities,	although	there	are	other	conditions	to	drawing	on	these	credit	facilities.

Additionally,	some	contracts	contain	certain	adequate	assurance	provisions	whereby	a	counterparty	may	demand	additional	collateral	based on	subjective	events	and/or	conditions.	Due	to	the	subjective	nature	of	these	provisions,	NEE	and	FPL	are	unable	to	determine	an	exact value	for	these	items	and	they	are	not	included	in	any	of	the	quantitative	disclosures	above.

## 4.	Non-Derivative	Fair	Value	Measurements

Non-derivative	fair	value	measurements	consist	of	NEE's	and	FPL's	cash	equivalents	and	restricted	cash	equivalents,	special	use	funds and	other	investments.	The	fair	value	of	these	financial	assets	is	determined	by	using	the	valuation	techniques	and	inputs	as	described in	Note	3	-	Fair	Value	Measurements	of	Derivative	Instruments	as	well	as	below.

Cash	Equivalents and	Restricted	Cash	Equivalents -	NEE	and	FPL	hold	investments	in	money	market	funds.	The	fair	value	of	these	funds	is estimated	using	a	market	approach	based	on	current	observable	market	prices.

Special	Use	Funds	and	Other	Investments -	NEE	and	FPL	hold	primarily	debt	and	equity	securities	directly,	as	well	as	indirectly	through commingled	funds.	Substantially	all	directly	held	equity	securities	are	valued	at	their	quoted	market	prices.	For	directly	held	debt securities,	 multiple	 prices	 and	 price	 types	 are	 obtained	 from	 pricing	 vendors	 whenever	 possible,	 which	 enables	 cross-provider validations.	A	primary	price	source	is	identified	based	on	asset	type,	class	or	issue	of	each	security.	Commingled	funds,	which	are similar	to	mutual	funds,	are	maintained	by	banks	or	investment	companies	and	hold	certain	investments	in	accordance	with	a	stated	set	of objectives.	 The	 fair	 value	 of	 commingled	 funds	 is	 primarily	 derived	 from	 the	 quoted	 prices	 in	 active	 markets	 of	 the	 underlying securities.	Because	the	fund	shares	are	offered	to	a	limited	group	of	investors,	they	are	not	considered	to	be	traded	in	an	active market.

Fair	Value	Measurement	Alternative -NEE	holds	investments	in	equity	securities	without	readily	determinable	fair	values,	which	are initially	recorded	at	cost,	of	approximately	$538	million	and	$485	million	at	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	respectively,	and	are	included in	noncurrent	other	assets	on	NEE's	consolidated	balance	sheets.	Adjustments	to	carrying	values	are	recorded	as	a	result	of	observable price	changes	in	transactions	for	identical	or	similar	investments	of	the	same	issuer.

Recurring	 Non-Derivative	 Fair	 Value	 Measurements -	 NEE's	 and	 FPL's	 financial	 assets	 and	 other	 fair	 value	 measurements	 made	 on	 a recurring	basis	by	fair	value	hierarchy	level	are	as	follows:

questions.question: How did Southern Company's funding approach for non-qualified defined benefits evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this multi-year pattern indicate about the company's long-term compensation strategy for executive employees?
questions.answer: Southern Company consistently funded non-qualified defined benefits on a cash basis across all three years (2022, 2023, and 2024), indicating a stable and immediate payment approach rather than pre-funding these obligations. This consistent methodology suggests the company maintained a conservative and liquidity-focused strategy for compensating a select group of management and highly compensated employees, without altering its funding mechanism despite potential changes in tax positions or pension plan dynamics over the period.

Hop 2: [SO](2023) → Non-Qualified Defined Benefits: Continued cash basis funding, with no mandatory contributions to qualified pension plans anticipated.
Hop 3: [SO](2024) → Non-Qualified Defined Benefits: Maintained cash basis funding structure, with no contributions made to qualified pension plans and none anticipated for the following year.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
The unrecognized tax positions increase from prior periods for 2020 and the balance of unrecognized tax benefits at December 31, 2020 and 2021 primarily relate to a 2019 state tax filing position to exclude certain gains from 2019 dispositions from taxation in a certain unitary state. If accepted by the state, this position would decrease Southern Company's annual effective tax rate. The ultimate outcome of this unrecognized tax benefit is dependent on completion of the related state audit, which is not expected to be resolved within the next 12 months.

All of the Registrants classify interest on tax uncertainties as interest expense. Accrued interest for all tax positions was immaterial for all years presented. None of the Registrants accrued any penalties on uncertain tax positions.

The IRS has finalized its audits of Southern Company's consolidated federal income tax returns through 2020. Southern Company is a participant in the Compliance Assurance Process of the IRS. The audits for the Registrants' state income tax returns have either been concluded, or the statute of limitations has expired, for years prior to 2015.

## 11. RETIREMENT BENEFITS

The Southern Company system has a qualified defined benefit, trusteed pension plan covering substantially all employees, with the exception of PowerSecure employees. The qualified pension plan is funded in accordance with requirements of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended (ERISA). No contributions to the qualified pension plan were made for the year ended December 31, 2021 and no mandatory contributions to the qualified pension plan are anticipated for the year ending December 31, 2022. The Southern Company system also provides certain non-qualified defined benefits for a select group of management and highly compensated employees, which are funded on a cash basis. In addition, the Southern Company system provides certain medical care and life insurance benefits for retired employees through other postretirement benefit plans. The traditional electric operating companies fund other postretirement trusts to the extent required by their respective regulatory commissions. Southern Company Gas has a separate unfunded supplemental retirement health care plan that provides medical care and life insurance benefits to employees of discontinued businesses. For the year ending December 31, 2022, no contributions to any other postretirement trusts are expected.
